author: Andy Dunn
title: Sean Dyche should be on the shortlist to replace Arsene Wenger at Arsenal... but he won't be
text:
Sport Opinion Sean Dyche should be on the shortlist to replace Arsene Wenger at Arsenal... but he won't be Right now, there is a glass ceiling for British managers Share Sean Dyche has impressed at Burnley (Photo: Sunderland AFC) Share Get Arsenal   Thank you for subscribing!   
In the extremely unlikely event of Arsene Wenger calling it a day, if you drew up a shortlist to succeed him, Sean Dyche would not be on it. 
Should be, wouldn’t be. 
Maybe his voice does not fit, but there is not the remotest chance Arsenal would turn to Dyche. 
Right now, there is a glass ceiling for British managers and it is probably only Eddie Howe who has a stab at breaking through it. 
Howe and Dyche have been in their current jobs for roughly the same time – the latter taking over from the former when he left Burnley to return to Bournemouth. 
In the Premier League, Howe and Dyche, ahead of Bournemouth’s game against Watford, had both managed in 59 fixtures. 
With 18 wins and 13 draws, Howe had collected 67 points and Dyche, with 15 wins and 14 draws, 59. Arsene Wenger looks set to carry on at Arsenal (Photo: Arsenal via Getty) 
Not much between them and in the four and a quarter years of their tenures, Dyche has spent, net, considerably less than Howe, roughly £20million less. Unlike Howe in that time, he has suffered a relegation, but Dyche’s net spend has been around the £25m mark which makes the job he has done at Burnley even more remarkable. 
Bringing them straight back to the Premier League was an outstanding achievement. 
A Big Six club, though, will be beyond Dyche. It probably doesn’t help he appears to have a king-sized chip on his shoulder. 
Earlier in the season, his comments on how foreign coaches get undue praise was eerily reminiscent of the Sam Allardici moment. 
This was part of Dyche’s diatribe. 
“Conte came in at Chelsea and got commended for bringing a hard, fast, new leadership which involved doing 800m runs, 400m runs, 200m runs. 
“Come to my training and see Sean Dyche doing that and you’d say ‘dinosaur, a young English dinosaur manager, hasn’t got a clue.’” 
Firstly, referring to yourself in the third person is never a great look and, secondly, Conte mainly gets commended for his brilliant record. 
But Dyche had a point. Antonio Conte has uses similar methods to Dyche (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
Foreign coaches tend to get lauded for the diets they introduce – banning tomato ketchup, that sort of thing – as if British coaches run their staff canteen like a greasy spoon. 
Maybe one of the reasons Brits might be unfairly overlooked is that, quite simply, a very cosmopolitan league is suited to cosmopolitan managers. 
There remains a deep-rooted insularity about British managers and it is easy to see how that counts against them. 
And Dyche has built a very British team. Of the 14 players used against Southampton in Burnley’s last league game, only one was from outside these Isles. 
Yet what Dyche has done is improve players – take Michael Keane as a shining example – and get his group punching above its weight. 
Surely, those are fundamental qualities that should make him eminently employable by a club, for example, the size of Arsenal. 
He will not be employed by one the size of Arsenal. 
He would not even be on the shortlist if Wenger walked. 
Chip on his shoulder or not, being British means there is only so far he can go. Like us on Facebook
